test_strategy.unit: Jest for Node.js (NestJS) services and Pytest for Python (FastAPI) AI workers. Heavy usage of mocking for external dependencies (CCXT, Database Repositories) to isolate business logic. Focus on mathematical accuracy for portfolio calculations and sentiment scoring algorithms.
test_strategy.integration: Supertest for API endpoint verification. Testcontainers to spin up ephemeral PostgreSQL (TimescaleDB) and Redis instances for realistic data persistence and Pub/Sub testing. Specific focus on the 'Exchange Connection Service' to verify encryption/decryption flows without hitting real external exchanges (using Nock/VCR to record/replay CCXT responses).
test_strategy.e2e: Playwright for full-stack verification. Scenarios will run against a staging environment with 'Sandbox' exchange keys (e.g., Binance Testnet). Tests will cover the critical path: Login -> Connect Exchange -> View Dashboard -> Execute Trade -> Verify Order History.
test_strategy.approach: Shift-Left testing strategy with strict quality gates in the CI/CD pipeline. Automated regression suites run on every PR. Performance testing is treated as a first-class citizen due to the low-latency requirement of trading terminals.

test_cases.name: Secure Exchange Connection & Validation
test_cases.description: Verify that a user can submit API keys, the system validates them via CCXT, and stores them encrypted.
test_cases.expected_result: System returns 200 OK, connection status is 'connected', and database record contains encrypted strings, not plain text.
test_cases.gherkin:
Given a user is authenticated AND has valid Binance API credentials
When the user submits the API Key and Secret via POST /api/v1/exchanges/connect
Then the system should validate permissions with Binance
And the API keys should be stored using AES-256 encryption in the database
And the response should confirm the connection status as 'connected'

test_cases.name: Real-time Order Execution (Limit Buy)
test_cases.description: Verify the full flow of placing a limit order from the UI through to the exchange API.
test_cases.expected_result: Order is successfully placed on the exchange, and the UI updates the Order Book and Open Orders list within 500ms.
test_cases.gherkin:
Given the user is on the Trading Terminal for BTC/USDT
When the user enters a Limit Buy order for 0.01 BTC at $30,000
And clicks 'Buy BTC'
Then the order should be routed to the Exchange API via CCXT
And the user should receive a success notification
And the 'Open Orders' table should display the new order

test_cases.name: Portfolio Aggregation Accuracy
test_cases.description: Verify that the Portfolio Service correctly sums balances across multiple exchanges and converts to USD.
test_cases.expected_result: Total Balance equals the sum of (Asset Quantity * Current Price) for all connected exchanges.
test_cases.gherkin:
Given User A has 1 BTC on Binance and 10 ETH on Coinbase
And the current price of BTC is $50k and ETH is $3k
When the Portfolio Summary is requested
Then the Total Balance should be calculated as $80,000
And the asset allocation pie chart data should reflect these proportions

test_cases.name: Price Alert Triggering
test_cases.description: Verify that the Alerts Processor triggers a notification when price conditions are met.
test_cases.expected_result: Notification service (mocked) receives a request to send an email/push within 30 seconds of price breach.
test_cases.gherkin:
Given a user has set an alert for 'ETH > $4000'
When the Market Data Streamer receives an ETH price update of $4005
Then the Alerts Processor should evaluate the condition as true
And a notification event should be published to the notification queue

test_cases.name: AI Sentiment Service Isolation
test_cases.description: Ensure the Python AI service can process news and update Redis without blocking the main Node.js API.
test_cases.expected_result: Sentiment score is updated in Redis, and the Node.js API serves the cached value instantly.
test_cases.gherkin:
Given the Python AI worker is running
When new headlines are ingested and processed
Then the sentiment score in Redis should be updated
And a subsequent GET /api/v1/market/sentiment request should return the new score with < 50ms latency

test_cases.name: API Rate Limit Enforcement
test_cases.description: Verify that the API Gateway throttles excessive requests to protect downstream exchange limits.
test_cases.expected_result: Requests exceeding the limit return 429 Too Many Requests.
test_cases.gherkin:
Given the rate limit is set to 10 requests/minute for exchange connections
When a malicious client sends 15 connection requests in 30 seconds
Then the 11th request should be rejected with HTTP 429
And the system should not attempt to contact the external exchange

auth_verification_steps: Verify Auth0 JWT signature validation on all protected routes.
Attempt to access protected endpoints with an expired token (expect 401).
Attempt to access protected endpoints with a valid token but insufficient scopes (expect 403).
Verify that API Secrets are never returned in API responses (even for the owner).
Test Session Revocation: Ensure logging out invalidates the session immediately.
security_plan.vulnerability_scan_strategy: Weekly automated OWASP ZAP scans against the staging environment. Snyk integration in the CI pipeline to block PRs with high-severity dependency vulnerabilities (npm/pip). Static Application Security Testing (SAST) using SonarQube on every commit.

manual_verification_steps: Verify the visual integrity of the Charting Library (TradingView) on mobile devices (375px width).
Check Dark Mode contrast ratios to ensure text is readable in low-light conditions.
Simulate a 'Network Disconnect' while a trade is processing to verify UI error handling and recovery state.
Manually verify the 'Export to CSV' format by importing the generated file into Koinly/CoinTracker.
Usability test: Verify that the 'Connect Exchange' form provides clear error messages when invalid API keys are pasted.

risk_analysis.risk:
Exchange API Rate Limiting (IP Ban from Binance/Coinbase). by proxying too many user requests from a single server IP, the platform could be banned by exchanges, halting all trading for all users. High Impact, Medium Probability. Mitigation: Implement strict internal rate limiting per user. Use a pool of rotating proxy IPs for the backend if volume scales significantly. Implement exponential backoff in the CCXT adapter wrapper. Verification: Load test with mocked rate-limit headers to ensure backoff logic triggers correctly. Monitor 'X-MBX-USED-WEIGHT' headers from Binance in production logs. Coverage: 85% branch coverage on the 'ExchangeAdapter' module to ensure all error handling paths (429, 5xx) are tested. Performance Metrics: P95 API Response Time: < 200ms. Database Query Time: < 50ms (for hot path). Page Load Time: < 1.5s. Time to Interactive: < 2.0s. Summary: The QA strategy for TradePulse focuses on the reliability and speed of the 'Layer 2' trading experience. Given the financial nature of the application, testing prioritizes the accuracy of portfolio calculations and the security of API credential storage. A hybrid approach using Jest for logic and Playwright for E2E flows ensures that both the backend math and the frontend execution work seamlessly. Special attention is paid to mocking external exchange interactions to prevent flakiness and avoid rate limits during CI runs. Description: This Quality Assurance Plan adopts a 'Risk-Based Testing' methodology. We identify the highest risk areas—specifically Order Execution and API Key Security—and allocate the densest test coverage there. 

**Testing Layers:**
1. **Unit Tests**: Focused on the `PortfolioService` (math accuracy) and `EncryptionService` (security). We use Jest for Node.js and Pytest for the Python AI worker.
2. **Integration Tests**: Focused on the `ExchangeAdapter` (CCXT wrapper). We use Testcontainers to spin up a real Redis instance to verify the Pub/Sub flow for market data updates.
3. **E2E Tests**: Focused on the 'Happy Path' of a trader: Login -> Connect -> Trade. These run against a Staging environment connected to Exchange Testnets (Sandbox).

**Performance & Security:**
Performance tests using k6 will simulate high-frequency price updates to ensure the WebSocket gateway doesn't choke. Security testing includes automated dependency scanning and specific tests to verify that the database never holds plain-text API secrets. Coverage: Branches: 80, Functions: 85, Lines: 85, Percentage: 85, Statements: 85, Threshold: 80. Performance Metrics: api_response_time_p95: 200ms, database_query_time: 50ms, first_contentful_paint: 1.0s, largest_contentful_paint: 2.5s, page_load_time: 1.5s, recommendations: ['Implement Redis caching for Portfolio Summary endpoints.', 'Use WebSocket compression (permessage-deflate) to reduce bandwidth.', 'Lazy load the TradingView chart library to improve FCP.'], time_to_interactive: 2.0s. Risk Analysis: Impact: High, Mitigation: Implement strict internal rate limiting per user. Use a pool of rotating proxy IPs for the backend if volume scales significantly. Implement exponential backoff in the CCXT adapter wrapper., Risk: Exchange API Rate Limiting (IP Ban). Impact: High, Mitigation: Use 'Sandbox' keys for E2E tests. Mock CCXT responses for Integration tests. Never use real funds for automated testing., Risk: Financial Loss during Automated Testing. Impact: Medium, Mitigation: Decouple the AI service via a message queue (Redis/BullMQ). Ensure the trading terminal works even if sentiment data is stale or unavailable., Risk: AI Service Latency affecting Trading UI. Impact: High, Mitigation: Implement Application-Level Encryption (AES-256) before writing to DB. Rotate Master Keys periodically., Risk: API Key Leakage via DB Dump. Summary: The QA strategy prioritizes the security of user assets (API keys) and the latency of the trading terminal. By leveraging Testcontainers for integration testing and Playwright for E2E, we ensure robust coverage of the distributed microservices architecture while mocking external dependencies to maintain CI stability. Description: The plan employs a pyramid testing structure. The base is a heavy suite of Unit Tests covering the mathematical logic of portfolio aggregation and the encryption utilities. The middle layer consists of Integration Tests verifying the interaction between the NestJS API, Redis, and TimescaleDB, specifically focusing on the event-driven nature of price updates. The top layer is a concise suite of E2E tests verifying the critical user journey. Security testing is integrated into the pipeline, ensuring no unencrypted secrets or vulnerable dependencies reach production. Performance benchmarks are set aggressively to match the 'Bloomberg Terminal' vision. Coverage: Branches: 80, Functions: 85, Lines: 85, Percentage: 85, Statements: 85, Threshold: 80. Description: The plan employs a pyramid testing structure. The base is a heavy suite of Unit Tests covering the mathematical logic of portfolio aggregation and the encryption utilities. The middle layer consists of Integration Tests verifying the interaction between the NestJS API, Redis, and TimescaleDB, specifically focusing on the event-driven nature of price updates. Summary: The QA strategy prioritizes the security of user assets (API keys) and the latency of the trading terminal. By leveraging Testcontainers for integration testing and Playwright for E2E, we ensure robust coverage of the distributed microservices architecture while mocking external dependencies to maintain CI stability. Description: The plan employs a pyramid testing structure. The base is a heavy suite of Unit Tests covering the mathematical logic of portfolio aggregation and the encryption utilities. The middle layer consists of Integration Tests verifying the interaction between the NestJS API, Redis, and TimescaleDB, specifically focusing on the event-driven nature of price updates. The top layer is a concise suite of E2E tests verifying the critical user journey. Security testing is integrated into the pipeline, ensuring no unencrypted secrets or vulnerable dependencies reach production.
